text: "Lemon Tree" is a popular song by the German band

, released in 1995 as part of their album *Dish of the Day*. The song became an international hit, reaching high positions on music charts across Europe and Asia. The lyrics describe a person sitting alone under a lemon tree, waiting for someone who never comes. The

‚Äîthe singer feels stuck in a passive state, much like how a lemon tree just stands there, not moving or changing.  

Key lines like:  
*"I'm sitting here in a boring room, it's just another rainy Sunday afternoon"*  
and  
*"I'm wasting my time, I got nothing to do, I'm hanging around, I'm waiting for you"*  

suggest
. The "yellow lemon tree" could also represent
‚Äîsomething bright and appealing, yet ultimately sour and unfulfilling.

Are prettier far than these.

text.text: : My name is Walter Harris. I'm 53 years old. I come from El Paso, Texas. I don't have much to offer. Just a tired voice, rough hands, and a heart that's been hurting for a very long time. I'm here tonight not because I'm chasing fame, but because I lost someone I've never stopped looking for. My son, Elijah. He was eight when his mother took him and left. She moved to Portland, Oregon. Or at least, that's where I heard she went. I don't even know if they stayed there. It's been so long, I don't know where he is now. I was at work when it happened. When I got home, the house was quiet, and he was gone. I didn't have a lawyer. I didn't have anyone to fight for me. So I worked. I built roofs in the heat, dug ditches, ate alone. Every night, I'd whisper his name like a prayer. Sometimes I'd talk to his photo, asking how his day went, just to feel like I was still his dad. They say time heals, but time doesn't know what it's like to lose a child. Every birthday, every holiday, I sat in silence hoping, just hoping, he might remember me. But nothing ever came. No calls, no letters, just the sound of years passing by. I never remarried, never moved on. My heart stayed with that little boy, frozen in time. And maybe he's grown now. Maybe he's forgotten me. But I never forgot him. Not for one minute. I never stopped loving him. I never stopped being his father. That's why I'm here. To sing a song I wrote for him. Because if he's out there, if he's watching, I want him to hear this. This is for you, Elijah, from your dad.
